awd_titl_txt: II-NEW: A Robot Testbed for Real-Time Motion Strategies and Autonomous Personal Assistants
awd_abstract_narration:
This infrastructure proposal supports the acquisition of a personal robot and a high-end multi-
GPU workstation to develop a new robot testbed for designing and evaluating the next generation of parallel
robot algorithms and open-source software systems on modern commodity computing platforms. The robot
platform will be based on a Meka M1 robot, a state-of-the-art robot with compliant, dextrous arms plus
camera and range sensors. This robot will be used to develop a new set of motion strategy and planning
algorithms and evaluate the capabilities of the robots for two driving applications: (1) assisting older adults
and people with disabilities with activities of daily living and (2) active tele-presence to give people in a
remote environment the ability to physically interact with people in the robot?s environment.

This robot testbed could lead to novel technologies for the development of personal
robots for assistance with tasks of daily living and active telepresence. These new capabilities could significantly
improve the quality of life for the elderly, people with disabilities, and other individuals. The development
of real-time motion strategies could also benefit other areas, such as surgical simulation, CAD/CAM,
virtual prototyping, and virtual reality environments. The software libraries developed under this project
would be made widely available through the public-domain release for all research and educational activities
across science, engineering, and medical domains. Teh research team will also integrate research with education, reach out
to under-represented groups via programs such as the IBM-sponsored Girls? summer camps, actively involving
undergraduates in the proposed research, and organizing workshops on many-core computing for real-time
motion strategies. Finally, the team expects the new robotics curriculum enabled by the proposed equipment acquisition
to help increase enrollment in Computer Science.

por.por_cntn:
This infrastructure grant provided the necessary equipment to conduct research in robotics and related areas. In particular, it was used to develop realtime algorithms for motion planning of high Degrees-of-freedom robots, while taking into account various constraints. The resulting algorithms were integrated with noisy sensor data and evaluated on scenarios provided by industrial collaborators. Furthermore, they are used for safe motion planning for human-robot interaction.

 

A high number of undergraduate and graduate students used the equipment for their education and research. Furthermore, the equipment is frequently used to give technology demonstrations to visitors, including middle and high school students.

 

Many video demonstrations of the technologies using this grant are available at:

 

1. http://gamma.cs.unc.edu/ITOMP   High dimensional optimization planning for dynamic environments. It was used for Amazon Picking challenging and Cartesian planning for industrial applications. It was applied to high DOF human-like robots and animation applications.

 

2. http://gamma.cs.unc.edu/SafeMP: The realtime motion planning has been integrated with human motion prediction algorithms that use depth sensors to detection and predict human actions. The realtime planner computes safe paths to avoid collisions with the humans in human-robot environments.

 

3. http://gamma.cs.unc.edu/SafeMP/NLP: The realtime planner has been integrated with natural language processing technologies (NLP). The natural language commands and instructions given by the humans are used to generate appropriate motion plans for the robot.

 

All the publications supported by this grant are available at:

https://wwwx.cs.unc.edu/~geom/papers/all/
